title-group.article-title: Modelling natural gas, renewables-sourced electricity, and ICT trade on economic growth and environment: evidence from top natural gas producers in Africa

institution-wrap.institution: Faculty of Economics and Political Science
National Center for Social and Criminological Research

abstract.title: Abstract
abstract.p: Addressing extensive global goals including growing energy-sourced electricity and advancing sustainable development plans strongly depends on natural gas as a transition fuel to renewable forms of energy. Therefore, by using pooled, random, and fixed-effects models, the current study investigates the effects of electricity sourced from natural gas (ENG), renewable energy (RE), and trade in information and communication technologies (ICTs) on economic growth and carbon dioxide (CO2) emissions in Africa’s top three natural gas producers, Algeria, Egypt, and Nigeria, from 1990 to 2020. The findings indicate that CO2, ENG, ICT trade, and urbanization (UP) are all strongly and positively correlated to economic progress, with the exception of RE, which has an insignificant influence. For the environment, data indicate that RE and GDP degrade the environment while ENG and ICT trade boost it. The causality results that ENG and RE cause both economic growth and CO2 emissions. Based on these empirical results, it is recommended that policymakers should step up their efforts to usage natural gas as a transition fuel to renewable energy sources and acknowledge the advantages of the significant contribution that green ICT trade can make to economic advancement and a clean environment.

custom-meta.meta-value: Springer-Verlag GmbH Germany, part of Springer Nature
Waste Water Technology / Water Pollution Control / Water Management / Aquatic Pollution

notes.title: Highlights
notes.p: • Impacts of natural gas, renewable energy, and ICT trade on economic growth.
• Impacts of natural gas, renewable energy, and ICT trade on the environment.
• Natural gas, CO2 and ICT trade enhance economic growth.
• ICT trade and natural gas improve environmental quality.

notes.title: Copyright comment
notes.p: Springer Nature or its licensor (e.g. a society or other partner) holds exclusive rights to this article under a publishing agreement with the author(s) or other rightsholder(s); author self-archiving of the accepted manuscript version of this article is solely governed by the terms of such publishing agreement and applicable law.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Energy-sourced electricity has lately focused the consideration of investors, traders, policymakers, and producers; partially, due to human activities, modernization, and the industrial revolution, in addition to, socioeconomic developments such as rapid population expansion and urbanization (Ibrahiem and Hanafy 2021). Globally, balancing economic development with environmental protection has received a lot of attention, and the energy mix processes increase in an initiative to shift energy systems away from dependence on fossil fuels and toward alternatives with a lower carbon footprint (Sarkodie and Adams 2018).

Under the energy mix considerations, natural gas is viewed as a “transition fuel” toward more ecological, cleaner, and climate-friendly energy production (Ibrahiem 2015; Esily et al. 2022a, b). Moreover, in all energy scenarios, natural gas production and consumption are predicted to grow steadily, and it will receive the majority of investment within the oil and gas industry (plc 2019; Cozzi et al. 2020; Gas Exporting Countries Forum 2021). Additionally, the logical direction of the energy mix is also renewable energies use, which helps satisfy the world’s expanding energy needs while also improving global ecological qualities (Olabi and Abdelkareem 2022).

Parallel to economic growth and environmental attention, information and communication technology (ICT), innovation and increasing power demand are shaping all parts of the economy nowadays (Olabi and Abdelkareem 2022). The implementation of the design to construction necessary for long-term economic growth depends on ICT trade. Economic progress is significantly impacted by the expansion of ICT trade, which boosts technology penetration, innovation, and cost-effective growth while also enhancing demand and energy efficiency. Meanwhile, the ICT trade sector may be used to increase environmental quality in manufacturing processes, transportation networks, and electrical grids (An Hign et al. 2017; Solarin et al. 2019).

It is significant to mention that improving the understanding of driver factors of economic progress and environmental deterioration are not only relevant for realizing sustainable growth but are also important for catalyzing the worldwide transition to low-carbon, ecologically friendly energy processes. Moreover, the most significant challenge confronting energy security in the next 20 years will be lowering pollution in the electricity generation sector while still meeting rapidly expanding demand for electricity, particularly in developing nations.

African countries are no exception to this approach, particularly, Algeria, Egypt, and Nigeria nations as Africa’s top producers of natural gas; according to British Petroleum (BP), Algeria, Egypt, and Nigeria are the top three natural gas producers in Africa (Agency 2017). As revealed in Fig. 1, natural gas production for Algeria, Egypt, Nigeria, and total Africa. The total NG production in the last 5 years is steady in Algeria and Nigeria, about 90 and 50 bcf, respectively. Egypt’s NG production increased from 42.5 bcf in 2015 to 58.4 bcf in 2020. These countries have come a long way in terms of utilizing natural gas for electrical generation. According to Energy Information Administration (EIA), despite the government’s efforts to expand Egypt’s energy mix, fossil energies, notably petroleum and natural gas, still provide greater than 95% of the nation’s primary energy. The generation of electricity met more than 60% of overall NG demand (US EIA 2018).Fig. 1
Natural gas production (bcf) for Algeria, Egypt, Nigeria, and total Africa (Data source: BP, 2021)

Furthermore, as seen in Figs. 2 and 3, the chosen countries are experiencing accelerated environmental degradation and economic expansion related to energy demand. The total emissions of carbon dioxide of these three countries emitted from energy use increased sharply within the latest 10 years recording about a 50% increase. And this is linked with the increase in economic progress whereas these three less-developed nations are trying to develop all the economic sectors such as transport, industry, building, and power sectors. Therefore, developing nations strive to make the long-term transition from coal to gas and renewable energy sources.Fig. 2
CO2 emissions (kt) for Algeria, Egypt, and Nigeria (Data source: WB, 2021)Fig. 3
GDP for Algeria, Egypt, and Nigeria (Data source: WB, 2021)

Moreover, Algeria, Egypt, and Nigeria all have a lot of potential for improving their energy capacity, especially for renewables. Algeria’s renewable energy and energy efficiency program set a prospective target represented in the dependence on renewable resources in generating about 40% of electricity production by 2030 (Stambouli et al. 2012). For Egypt, in its long-term development strategy, it establishes a goal: Egypt’s 2030 goal calls for renewable energies to elucidate for 42% of all electricity will be produced by 2035 (International Renewable Energy Agency 2018; Ibrahiem and Sameh 2020). Also, Nigeria continues to create its electricity 20% from renewable sources in public and 15.27% from solar energy by 2030 (Bamisile et al. 2017).

Therefore, the motivation of our research is to analyzing ENG, RE, ICT trade, and urbanization on economic progress and environmental during the data availability from 1990 to 2020 for Algeria, Egypt, and Nigeria using pooled, fixed, and random effects models.

This investigation enhances to the current literature in five techniques: (i) for all we recognize, this is the initial research of the major natural gas producers in Africa that focuses on both environmental protection and economic development. (ii) Disaggregated energy, which is broken down into renewables and natural gas, is utilized in the investigation. This is crucial for analyzing the effects of both energy sources on development in both the economy and the environment. (iii) It examines significant impact of ICT trade on economic growth and air pollution. (iv) In terms of econometric approach, pooling, fixed, and random effects models have been selected because they can produce estimates of the long-run parameters that are both dynamically diverse and consistent in the short run. (v) To investigate the causal connection between economic growth, carbon emissions and their drivers, the Granger causality test is used. Empirical evidence results show that with the exception of RE, which has a negligible impact, CO2, ENG, ICT trade, and UP are all strongly and positively associated with economic advancement. In terms of the environment, data show that ENG and ICT commerce improve it while RE and GDP deteriorate it. Since ENG and RE are causally related to both economic progress and CO2 emissions.

The following is the outline of the paper: overviews of the literature analysis on the drivers of economic progress and the environmental threats addressed will be covered in the survey of literature. Theoretical framework and hypotheses development are highlighted before methodology. The material and methods are reported in-depth in methodology section. The empirical results and discussion are highlighted and analyzed in empirical outcomes and discussions sections. Finally, conclusion and discussion of policy implications in Algeria, Egypt, and Nigeria will be reported.

sec.title: Literature review
sec.p: Due to massive scientific evidence that current energy systems are economically and environmentally unsustainable, academic discussions about sustainable power production and use have arisen. The importance of the rapid demand for electricity, along with the increasing contribution of natural gas and renewables in the energy equation, has been well documented. As a consequence, the driving variables are a priority for many academics from both an environmental and economic standpoint such as for the top ten economies in the world (Azam et al. 2021b), for the leading CO2 emitter countries (Azam et al. 2021a), and for China (Dong et al. 2018).

sec.title: Economic growth and environment nexus
sec.p: Enhancing economic progress has been one of the main objectives of economic policy and is a result of progress. But, over the past few decades, there has been much debate about the ecological implications of economic growth all over the world, especially in African economies. Economic growth is crucial for nations to develop their infrastructure over the past number of years. Therefore, more utilization power is required for growth as a result of increased economic activity. Natural gas and renewable energy sources are preferable over traditional fossil fuels in economic activity, which could result in increasing emissions that contribute to air pollution. As a result, environmental dangers and economic growth provide a conflict for both environmentalists and economists. Many scholars are interested in investigating the link between emissions of CO2 and GDP to examine if energy supply is independent of global economic growth or if economic growth is dependent on a country’s energy output. As a result, nations that associate significant energy use and emissions with economic growth. are found as for China (Li et al. 2021), for Malaysia (Ali et al. 2020), for sub-Saharan Africa (Garba and Bellingham 2021), for N11 nations (Esily et al. 2022c), and for Morocco (Bouyghrissi et al. 2021) while others demonstrated a decoupling between GDP and CO2 emissions (Chen et al. 2018; Eluwole et al. 2020; Bekaliyev et al. 2021). Given the advancements that African nations have made and are projected to make in the upcoming years, these discoveries are crucial for them. It also suggests that a research question is being addressed by the topic analysis.

sec.title: Energy sourced electricity, economic development, and the environment nexus
sec.p: Industrialized society is heavily reliant on electricity production to promote growth. Various studies conclude that natural gas and renewable sourced electricity enhance economic progress for Malaysia (Ali et al. 2020), for Bangladesh (Islam 2021), for China, for Pakistan (Rehman et al. 2020), for Egypt (Ouki 2018), and for Italy (Cerdeira Bento and Moutinho 2016). As a result, global natural gas electricity production has doubled within 50 years ago (IEA 2019). Other scholars confirmed no relation between electricity production and GDP as for Mexico (Massa and Rosellon 2020).

For the correlation between ENG and CO2 emissions is attracting more attention between scholars who showed the positive influence on CO2 such as a study for Italy (Cerdeira Bento and Moutinho 2016) and for Saudi Arabia (Algarini 2020). On another front, Dong et al. (2018), Rodrigues et al. (2020), Azam et al. (2021a, b) confirmed the benefits of natural gas in terms of lowering CO2 emissions where it is a readily available option for battling off impending environmental threats as well as efficiencies in the utilization of power have improved.

Additionally, all academics supported the role of renewables electricity on increasing environmental quality and recommended to accelerate the dependence on renewable energy sources in power generation such as Cerdeira Bento and Moutinho (2016), Moutinho and Robaina (2016), Alola et al. (2019), El Araby et al. (2019), Usama et al. (2020), Ramzan et al. (2021), Chandio et al. (2022), Sherif et al. (2022) except other limited researchers confirmed that renewables electricity increase CO2 emissions as Farhani and Shahbaz (2014), York and McGee (2017), and Balsalobre-Lorente et al. (2018). This connection appears to occur because renewable energy sources limit nuclear energy in affluent countries, thus maintaining reliance on fossil fuels, in addition, variations in renewable energy technology development might generate issues owing to a lack of operational skills, a lack of policies and regulations, and a lack of knowledge in the destination or a malfunction in the plant’s installation as mentioned in Qi et al. (2014) and Azam et al. (2021a, b). These assumptions are particularly important for the African nations, representing that the study issue is trying to close a knowledge gap. Differentiated sourced electricity, which is categorized as natural gas and renewables, is used in our investigation. When considering the impact of energy-sourced electricity on long-term environmental sustainability and economic expansion, this is absolutely crucial.

sec.title: ICT trade, economic development, and the environment nexus
sec.p: The process of large-scale investment in ICT trade as a type of technology has become the cornerstone of economic development plans, as it reduces capital costs and production costs. These technologies have enormous potential for increasing GDP as confirmed in much academic research for emerging Asian economies (Sharma et al. 2021), for EU countries (Magazzino et al. 2021), for the ASEAN-8 countries (Sapuan and Roly 2021), and for rich and poor countries which showed that ICT trade revolution benefits poor countries the most (Appiah-Otoo and Song 2021). However, other investigations resulted in a negative effect of ICT trade on GDP as for Gulf Cooperation Council (GCC) countries (Alshubiri et al. 2019), for selected South Asian economies (Usman et al. 2021), and for Korea (Sawng et al. 2021).

Less-developed economies are trying to harmonize ICT with CO2 emission goals. Despite the fact that ICT diminishes CO2 emissions as mentioned for middle and high-income economies (Zhang et al. 2019) and for 16 emerging countries (Haldar and Sethi 2022), other research projects showed that ICT enhances the reduction of CO2 emissions for China (Zhang and Liu 2015), for Pakistan (Godil et al. 2020), for emerging countries with a low level of income (N’dri et al. 2021), for Asia Pacific countries (Bhujabal et al. 2021), for newly industrialized countries (Adebayo et al. 2022), for sub-Saharan Africa (Bello et al. 2022), and for the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Lee and Brahmasrene 2014). However, there are some academics showed that CO2 emission is increased by ICT for Tunisia (Amri et al. 2019), for EU (Park et al. 2018), and Arab World (Hodrab et al. 2016). As a consequence, applying the findings of current research to the economies of top natural gas producers in Africa, which have also had tremendous economic growth, would be essential.

sec.title: Urbanization and economic development nexus
sec.p: Cities’ design, population density, and population size may all have a significant effect on economic expansion. The connection between urbanization and economic progress is a critical topic among academics, although the results are mixed. The literature review explored the correlation between urbanization and economic progress, because a deeper apprehension of the links between urbanization and economic progress is critical for universal future sustainable development. Hossain (2011), Kasman and Duman (2015), and Gao and Zhang (2021) found that there are one-way causal links from urbanization to GDP in the short run, while Zhao and Wang (2015) showed that the effect of urbanization on economic activity appears to be minor.

sec.title: Research gap
sec.p: Studies in the literature that consider the effects of both ecologically responsible criteria and productivity-boosting criteria in the same growth framework for developing nations are insufficient. These industries frequently focus on the electricity that is produced using traditional fuels; therefore, it is questionable if the use of renewable energy sources may allow rapid development without harming the environment. We consider the sustainability of the environment in this analysis while examining the effects of technical improvements on the economy by considering the impact of ICT as well as power production from natural gas and renewable sources. All of the aforementioned empirical research could indicate that not only are there still few studies on the drivers of GDP and CO2 emissions, but also that there is no evidence for studies on top natural gas producers in Africa in particular. As a consequence, given the importance of environmental quality and economic progress in Algeria, Egypt, and Nigeria, it appears necessary to assess the most important GDP and CO2 emissions drivers with an eye to succor policymakers in the recognition of the substantial drivers of these resources and formulating the indispensable and adequate policies to accomplish sustainable development objectives. The background literature reviewed in this section serves as the foundation for the development of our theoretical framework and assumptions in the next section.

sec.title: Theoretical framework and hypotheses development
sec.p: The relationship between ecological degradation and economic progress, electrical production, and ICT has been the focus of several hypotheses. The following theories are a few of the more prevalent ones:

sec.title: Effects of economic growing on environmental deterioration and vice versa
sec.p:
The hypothesis of the environmental Kuznets curve (EKC) outlines the link between expanding GDP and environmental deterioration; it essentially illustrates the cycle in which economic expansion degrades environmental quality before restoring (inverted U-shape). Grossman and Krueger (1995) identified three channels including scale effect, composition effect, and technique effect. When economic expansion dictates the economy path, the scale effect factors in. As a consequence, there is a growth in the demand for natural resources for use in manufacturing. Since an enormous amount of environmentally damaging industrial waste is produced, which results in both an increase in environmental deterioration and a rise in economic growth. While the composition effect is the gradual change in the industrial structure that takes place as income increases, changing the composition of the economy. When the secondary sector begins to mature and industries begin to adopt cleaner technology, which has a favorable impact on how well the environment is being treated as a result of economic expansion. This stage is responsible for a rise in the demand for a cleaner atmosphere, which then encourages technical advancement and economic expansion. Where the economy invests in R&D activities and becomes more knowledge intensive, the third sector or the service sector expands. Thus, it results in the replacement of polluting technology, which in turn improves the environment and boosts economic growth (Dinda 2004).
Hypothesis 1a. Economic growth decreases environmental deterioration.
Hypothesis 1b. Environmental deterioration increases economic growth.

sec.title: Effect of energy-sourced electricity on the economy and the environment
sec.p: Kraft and Kraft (1978) did the first investigation on the linkage between energy utilization and economic growth which has expanded to include the electricity-generation nexus. To determine if conservation strategies can be used without influencing the rate of development, such study is crucial. The “neutrality hypothesis,” a neo-classical viewpoint that claims that energy consumption has no discernible impact on economic progress and that, as a result, conservation policies can be implemented to diminish CO2 emissions without undermining the level of growth, has been supported by a number of studies such as Narayan (2016) which revealed that just 32 lower-middle-income nations support the energy consumption growth hypothesis, whereas the neutrality hypothesis stands for the majority of developing nations. In addition to physical and human capital, “growth hypothesis” proponents believe that energy is an element of production that contributes to economic progress. This invalidates the neo-classical “neutrality hypothesis” and claims that environmental protection measures may limit economic development. Meanwhile, a literature review by Omri (2014) revealed that just 27% of the country-level empirical studies endorse the conservation/neutrality hypothesis, whereas 40% of them endorse the growth hypothesis for the connection between electricity use and growth.

According to a number of studies, natural gas has been promoted as switching from fossil fuels to renewable energy. This shows that a substantial conversion to natural gas as a substitute fuel, including developing new engines and retrofitting old engines to use natural gas, is a feasible and efficient option (Kutcherov et al. 2017; Aguilera and Aguilera 2020). Furthermore, due to its possible long-term effects for environmental concerns, Many researchers (Chel and Kaushik 2018; Amjith and Bavanish 2022; Baloch et al. 2022) claimed that the most practical and efficient solution for a sustainable environment is renewable energy. As a result, a lot of academics are paying noteworthy attention to how natural gas and renewables are changing from an environmental and economic standpoint.

Since the energy sourced electricity is thought to be a crucial element in explaining the economic progress, with environmental concerns, we investigate the natural gas, renewables-sourced electricity consumption for top natural gas producers in Africa under the following hypothesis.
Hypothesis 2a. Natural gas-sourced electricity increases economic growth.
Hypothesis 2b. Natural gas-sourced electricity decreases environmental deterioration.
Hypothesis 2c. Renewable energy-sourced electricity increases economic growth.
Hypothesis 2d. Renewable energy-sourced electricity decreases environmental deterioration.

sec.title: Effects of ICT trade on the economy and the environment
sec.p: From the economic viewpoint, the correlation among ICT trade and economic expansion can be characterized using mainly two theories: the exogenous and endogenous growth theories. The exogenous growth theory views technology as being external to the growth model and is clarified inside the “Solow residual,” despite the fact that both theories have hypothesized the importance of technological progress. On the other side, the endogenous growth hypothesis views ICT trade as an endogenous that raises factor productivity. However, this is only feasible once a particular level of skill development and human capital has been attained (Crafts 1995).

From the environmental viewpoint, ICT trade affects the environment in three main ways: use, substitution, and cost effect. When the ICT trade mechanism is introduced to the economy, the use effect begins, increasing energy consumption. Production, installation, processing, and distribution all require a lot of energy, which produces hazardous electronic wastes such damaging carbon and nitrogen emissions that damage the environment (Shabani and Shahnazi 2019). It is followed by a substitution effect since investments grow when ICT trade infrastructure is deployed. The growing investment causes the productivity and efficiency of the mechanisms to increase, which in turn enhances energy efficiency. The next stage, sometimes referred to as the cost effect, is when demand for products and services increases as prices decline. As more people utilize the goods and services, this effect causes carbon emissions to rise (Danish 2019). The following hypothesis are put out in light of theoretical and empirical data regarding the direct and indirect consequences of ICT trade.
Hypothesis 3a. ICT trade increases economic growth.
Hypothesis 3b. ICT trade decreases environmental deterioration.

sec.title: Model specification
Sources of data
Estimation procedures
sec.p: The investigation is based on yearly panel data because of its many advantages such as the following: its ability to provide more evidence by integrating the time series and cross sections (countries), control for heterogeneity, and enhancement of the degrees of freedom available for valid analysis. Descriptive statistics was conducted as an initial step for investigation of the variables, and then the panel unit root tests were conducted to investigate the stationarity of the series under study. To realize the stochastic trend element in each variable, this study uses two prominent unit root tests proposed by Levin-Lin-Chu (LLC) (Levin et al. 2002) and Im-Pesaran-Shin (IPS) (Im et al. 2003). The null hypothesis of both tests affirms that the variables have a unit root, against not having a unit root as an alternative.

Then, one of the most fundamental diagnostics that any researcher should look at before using a panel data analysis is the cross-sectional dependence test. For this purpose, the Breusch and Pagan (1980) LM test, Pedroni (2004) CD test, Pedroni (2004) scaled LM test, and Baltagi (2012) bias-corrected scaled LM test were used.
In addition, the Pesaran second-generation CADF panel unit root test (Pedroni 2004) was used for the purpose of relaxing the cross-sectional independence assumption.

Next, to test the existence of co-integration between variables, two forms of co-integration tests were used, namely Pedroni (1999, 2004) and Kao (1999). Engle and Granger’s (1987) “two-step residual-based approach is used in these co-integration tests” (Engle and Granger 1987; Kao 1999; Pedroni 1999, 2004). Firstly, the Pedroni test depends on modified panel PP, panel ADF, and panel PP tests. Secondly, the Kao test is based on five test statistics, including modified panel DF, panel DF, panel ADF, unadjusted modified panel DF, and unadjusted panel DF.

Furthermore, there are three forms of panel data regression: pooled (OLS), random (REM) effects, and fixed (FEM) model. In addition, the robust least square (RLS) estimation is used since it offers numerous advantages over conventional least-squares approaches. To identify the validity of the panel data, we use the F, Hausman, and Breusch-Pagan tests. First, the null hypothesis of the F-test indicates that the pooled OLS model is superior to the fixed model. Second, the Hausman test’s null hypothesis illustrates that the random model is superior to the fixed model. Third, the Breusch-Pagan Lagrange Multiplier test’s null hypothesis identifies that the pooled OLS model is superior to the random one.

Moreover, a panel causality test introduced by Dumitrescu-Hurlin (2012) was used for checking causality in panel data and designing suitable recommendations based on the causality link between the variables analyzed. This model is relied on the statistics of two various tests: Z-bar and W-bar.

For the null hypothesis H0, it demonstrates that there are no causal links versus that there is causal link in one individual or more. H0 may be accepted if the significant values are less than estimated probability values and vice versa.

sec.title: Empirical findings
sec.p:
First, the results begin by summarizing the descriptive analysis of RE, CO2, ENU, ICT, GDP, and UPOP in Table 2. The results indicate that the mean values of the GDP and CO2 emissions are 2.19e + 11 and 118,745.5, respectively. Looking at the minimum and maximum values of GDP, CO2 emissions, and the independent variables, the ICT has the lowest value among the variables with 0 while the CO2 emission has the largest value with 265,298.6. For the standard deviation values of the variables are 1.20 + e11 for GDP, 49,767.56 for CO2, 5.727722 for RE, 17.16571 for ENG, 2.693778 for ICT, and 1.090538 for UPOP of the variables. With the exception of the GDP, most of the study’s variables show just minor variation with regards to the standards deviation. This improves the study model’s resilience and stability and solves the issue of inconsistent and variable data results.Table 2

Table 3 represents the result of the panel unit root test that most of regressors and regressand are not stationary at levels; therefore, the null hypothesis may be accepted. While, all the regressors and regressand turned to be stationary after taking the first difference at 1%, 5%, and 10% significance levels. So, the findings show that all the variables are integrated at order one I (1). On the other hand, this situation implies the possibility of a long-run association between the series under study.Table 3

In addition, before moving on to the estimation results, it is crucial to determine whether there is cross-sectional dependence between the variables under consideration and whether there is a long-term link between them by applying various cross-sectional dependency tests and co-integration tests, respectively, then identify the proper lag length selection criteria. First, Table 4 shows the results of vector auto-regressive lag order selection information criteria; the analysis determined that lag one was the ideal lag length based on in reference to all the information criteria except final prediction error information criteria. Second, Table 5 reports the findings of cross section dependency test which illustrate the rejection of the null hypothesis of cross-sectional independence at 1% significant level. This finding implies that the panel data suffer from cross dependence during the period of the study. So, to establish unbiased estimation, we have to apply first the Pesaran CADF test’s second-generation panel unit root test, reported in Table 6. The findings indicate that all the variables are non-stationary at level except (economic growth and renewable electricity net generation), as the corresponding p values are greater than the different significant levels. However, all these variables are turned to be stationary after taking the first difference at 1% significant level.Table 4

Then, Table 7 illustrates the findings of the two co-integration tests (Pedroni and Kao) tests for the first and the second model, GDP model 1 and CO2 emissions model 2. According to the outcomes for GDP model 1, all the statistics of Pedroni and Kao test are statistically significant at 1% and 5% significant level indicating the existence of long-run association between the series of the first model. Then, the findings for CO2 emissions model 2 show that only six of the eight results are statistically significant at various levels of significance, rejecting the null hypothesis. This shows that the series under consideration have a long-term association in models (1–2) After detecting the long-run relationship, then, we can estimate the pooled OLS, FEM, and REM models to grasp the relationships of regressors on economic progress and carbon dioxide emissions to choose the optimal model. Table 8 reports the estimation outcomes of each model. For GDP model 1, the results imply that the CO2, ENG, ICT, and UPOP have a positive significant influence on GDP, signifying that these variables enhance economic progress in the economies under consideration. Also, RE has a positive insignificant influence on GDP, which illustrates that RE is inadequate in stimulating the GDP of chosen three nations. For CO2 emissions model 2, the results reveal that the coefficients of GDP and RE are positive and significant. Otherwise, the impacts of ENG and ICT have a negative and significant influence on carbon dioxide emissions. In addition, for robustness check, the study uses the robust least square (RLS) estimation method which is reported also in Table 8. The findings indicate that all regressors are significant at different significant levels. For the first model, RLS shows that all the series have a positive and significant influence on GDP. For the second model, except for GDP, all regressors have a positive influence on CO2 emissions.Table 7

Moreover, for choosing the accurate model for regression prediction the study performs the F, Breusch-Pegan, and Hausmann tests. For the two models, F-test is calculated to compare the fixed model and pooled OLS. Table 9 represents that the FEM is better as the probability is less than 5%. Then, a Hausmann test is used to establish whether the panel data is a FEM or REM; the p value is less than 5%, implying that the fixed model is the appropriate one. Next, the Breusch-Pagan test is conducted to compare the random model and pooled OLS, and it shows that the pooled OLS is the better. Hence, the fixed model is the accurate regression model for this panel data.Table 9

Furthermore, Table 10 provides an overview of the results of the pairwise panel causality test. The crucial outcomes of this test show a bidirectional causal relationship between LnGDP and LnRE, LnCO2, LnENG, and LnUPOP, supporting the feedback hypothesis. Additionally, the one-way causality between LnICT and LnGDP testifies to the growth hypothesis’ applicability in the selected economies. On the other hand, the results also show that there is no causal relationship between LnCO2, LnRE, LnUPOP, and LnICT, while there is only a one-way causality of LnENG to LnCO2. Also, it is important to mention that have a statistically significant link between two variables means that the relationship observed in the sample exists in the population and it does not imply the presence of causality between those two variables at all.

table-wrap-foot.p: *** and ** imply the significance at 0.01 and 0.05 level, respectively

sec.title: Discussions
sec.p:
Table 8 and Fig. 5 show the summary of fixed model results for the two models. For model 1, the outcomes of the estimation of Eq. 1 reveal that all the regressors are significantly and positively linked with economic progress except renewable electricity that has an insignificant influence. Natural gas production is linked positively with economic growth, and this is in compliance with the expected impact on GDP and consistent with Ali et al. (2020) and Islam (2021). According to WB data 2021, these outcomes are consistent with our selected countries where electricity production from natural gas sources is the source with the highest share where it constitutes about 98.3, 70.7, and 81.8 of in total electricity production for Algeria, Egypt, and Nigeria, respectively, and thus, natural gas is considered a crucial energy source in enhancing economic growth by depending on it in several sectors like electricity, industrial, and transportation. Fig. 5
Fixed effect models findings representation for the study variables

Environmental degradation has a positive influence on economic progress, and this is relevant to our selected countries where the economic growth may be at the expense of the environment and thus environmental degradation can be considered a stimulus towards a shift to sustainable qualitative economic growth that mainly depends on clean energy sources. ICT trade enhances economic growth, and this is compatible with Magazzino et al. (2021) and Usman et al. (2021), where ICT trade increases economic expansion through poverty alleviation, employment generation, and raises productivity in several ways, one of which is the use of technology to improve the efficiency of operations, and it plays a pivotal role in improving decision-making. The positive insignificance influence of renewable electricity can be contributed to the fact that African countries’ usage of clean and renewable sources of energy is considerably low. This result provides a glimpse into the role of governments in African countries to promote the development of these clean energy sources to help in maintaining their position in global energy markets and promoting sustainable qualitative and quantitative economic progress.

Moreover, urbanization promotes economic growth by encouraging human development and enhancing productivity and by the establishment of special economic zones, industrial zones with their related strategic investments in two main areas; transport, communications, and commercial services sector (Turok and McGranahan 2013).

For model 2, the outcomes of the estimation of equation reveal that natural gas production and ICT trade improve environmental quality while economic growth and RE deteriorate the environment. Natural gas production has a negative influence on carbon dioxide emissions and this reveals the fact that African countries to a significant extent succeeded in accelerating the shift towards natural gas at the expense of oil and this happens by their significant dependence on natural gas for instance as a fuel for cars, thus, reducing carbon dioxide from the combustion process. It is also used in power plants and contributes to the manufacture of steel and plastics and is used in the chemical industries. Moreover, ICT trade negatively influences carbon dioxide emissions and this is in contradiction with Amri et al. (2019) but in line with Zhang and Liu (2015) and Asongu (2018), where ICT trade may improve environmental quality by its crucial role in reducing transportation costs and enhancing the financial affair related to business and households. It may also promote energy efficiency whether in the consumption of commodities or in transportation (Hilty et al. 2006; Amavilah et al. 2017; Asongu 2018).

The positive influence of renewable electricity on environmental degradation may be attributed to several factors associated with manufacturing and transporting these energy sources, especially solar energy manifested in the production of photovoltaic cells. Thus, the manufacturing processes can emit carbon dioxide as they mainly depend on non-renewable energies in building the needed resources for renewables, and this is in line with Farhani and Shahbaz (2014) and Balsalobre-Lorente et al. (2018) Additionally, economic growth deteriorates the environment as African being developing countries, their economic growth is still associated with environmental degradation manifested in obscene exploitation of natural resources in order to accommodate the needs of the population in terms of energy and food, also legislation may mismatch with the various social conditions by ignoring the environmental costs for production, together with the expansion of agricultural lands at the expense of marginal land.

The results of the pairwise Dumitrescu-Hurlin causality approach are shown in Table 10. The results of the pairwise causation test show that two-way causality exists between GDP and CO2 emissions and that the consequence is steady with the African region that is struggling to achieve high rates of economic progress at the cost of the quality of the environment particularly in the initial steps of development. However, natural gas producer countries in Africa are seeking to become in the staff of developed countries which abate pollution through energy transition from coal to gas and renewables where two-way causality is between GDP, electricity sourced from NG and RE (Esso and Keho 2016; Jebli and Youssef 2017). Also, unidirectional causality is running between economic progress and urbanization that is in the line with African countries which are in compliance with (Turok and McGranahan 2013). While one-way causality running from ICT trade to UPOP, ENG, and GDP are consistent with the results of Latif et al. (2018) and Murshed et al. (2020), and it means that these countries have to encourage using ICT trade for enhancing economic growth.

To sum up, in the long run, RE and ENG boost economic growth. Furthermore, carbon emissions are significantly influenced by GDP since economic progress in most economies is a necessity for the use of more energy, particularly electricity. GDP is stimulated by high emissions, such as traditional energy, but growth can also be attained through various decarburization productive activities, implying that GDP is slowly decoupling from carbon emissions.

sec.title: Conclusion and recommendations
sec.p: This paper examines the impact of electricity production from disaggregated energy sources, such as NG and RE, and ICT trade on GDP and CO2 emissions to secure economic growth and environmental sustainability in Algeria, Egypt, and Nigeria, three of Africa’s top natural gas producers. Furthermore, two model panels of GDP growth and CO2 emissions were run from 1990 to 2020 using panel regression methods including pooled OLS, FEM, REM, and RLS. With the exception of RE, which has a negligible impact on economic progress, the regression analysis results demonstrate that CO2, ENG, ICT trade, and urbanization (UPOP) are all strongly and positively linked to economic success. While environmental outcomes show that ENG and ICT trade help in reducing CO2 emissions, while RE and GDP help to increase them.

Since many developing nations have set goals for their environmental and economic development for the years 2030, 2040, and 2050, and since the countries under study are in comparable circumstances with regard to their natural gas production, policymakers in the natural gas industry should be committed to the Paris Agreement in order to take these goals into consideration and increase the efficiency of their efforts to combat climate change.

According to GECF 2020, Africa’s contribution of global gas production in 2030 and 2050 is 7.6% and 10.1%, respectively, in the total world (Gas Exporting Countries Forum 2021). In particular, Algeria and Egypt have maintained their positions as Africa’s largest gas producers but Nigeria is predicted to surpass them by 2050, producing more than 130 billion cubic meters. The government should pursue upstream, midstream, and downstream natural gas projects because natural gas has a significant relationship with GDP and because electricity production is dominated by NG, which makes NG-sourced energy crucial for long-term economic and environmental viability. Emissions from the natural gas supply chain can be reduced by managing intermittent flaring and venting, which is connected to both oil and gas wells, as well as bolstering the integrity of oil and gas assets and networks, according to McKinsey and Company’s 2020 report (McKinsey 2020).

If implemented with high accuracy and efficiency, renewable energy plays a key part in diminishing pollution throughout time. Solar resources are abundant in Sunbelt nations like Algeria, Egypt, and Nigeria, and overall annual average direct sun irradiation is high over the long term (Umoh and Garba 2013; Eldin et al. 2016; Bouchouicha et al. 2018). These nations have considerable potential for producing energy from sun, wind, hydro, geothermal, and biomass. By 2030, Algeria aims to have 27% of its energy mix come from renewable sources (Zahraoui et al. 2021). Egypt’s Vision 2030 aims to generate at least 30% of its electricity from renewable sources by the year 2050 (International Renewable Energy Agency 2018). Nigeria’s renewable energy goal is to increase the amount of renewable energy in the country’s electricity mix to 30% by 2030, with solar energy making up 19% of that mix (National Council on Power 2016).

Policymakers should also take into account blue hydrogen, which is created from natural gas but has had its CO2 emissions decreased through the use of carbon capture, utilization, and storage, and green hydrogen, which is produced from renewable sources. In addition to being more affordable than alternative energy sources, hydrogen generation is a transitional energy source that may use resources and infrastructure already in place. As a result, hydrogen has the potential to both increase energy diversification, which is essential in a low-carbon economy, and contribute to achieving climate goals (‘The Future of Hydrogen’, 2019; Esily et al. 2022a, b).

Enhancing ICT trade openness is also a significant step toward developing cleaner energy sources. In considerable detail, the best option for ensuring a sustainable economy and environment is to implement green energy technologies and energy-saving practices through ICT trade. Overall, it is recommended that RE and ICT trade could be useful tools for boosting GDP and minimizing environmental harm. It is crucial to note that the unanticipated COVID-19 pandemic, which started in 2020, has posed a threat to the globe and its nations and has had a detrimental effect on the development of the energy industry, which has grown at an unprecedented rate (Ayittey et al. 2020). Therefore, governments and politicians everywhere must make crucial efforts, such as increased investment in clean energy research and development programs is required in the future.

Due to different ecological issues, we focused on CO2 emissions in this research; nevertheless, we recommend adding ecological footprints to the analysis in future studies to enhance the study’s scope. By examining the legislative aspect as well as the significance of foreign indirect investments in the renewable productions and hydrogen strategies of the African economies, additional studies can improve the body of existing literature. This will help to address ecological concerns, reduce the unintended and undesirable consequences of the relevant issues, and remain committed to their objectives.

ack.title: Acknowledgements
ack.p: Rehab R. Esily is a recipient of a PhD fellowship from Missions Sector, Higher Education Ministry, Egypt, in association with the Chinese Scholarship Council (CSC).

sec.title: Author contribution
sec.p: Rehab R. Esily, Yuanying Chi, and Dalia M. Ibrahiem designed research. Rehab R. Esily and Dalia M. Ibrahiem data curation and wrote the paper. Nourhane Houssam analyzed the data. Yuanying Chi, Dalia M. Ibrahiem, and Yahui Chen revised this paper. All authors read and approved the final manuscript.

sec.title: Data availability
sec.p: Data is available at World Bank (https://databank.worldbank.org/source/world-development-indicators) and at the Energy Information Administration (https://www.eia.gov/).

sec.title: Ethics approval and consent to participate
sec.p: Not applicable.

sec.title: Consent for publication
sec.p: Not applicable.

sec.title: Competing interests
sec.p: The authors declare no competing interests.
